task_title: Enlarge and rebalance hero text block on home page
repo_context: This project is a personal portfolio site.

The hero section currently has an illustration on the left and, on the right, a text block with the name 'MARIO CAMARENA', a short tagline about being a CS Master's student at UTRGV, and two primary buttons (view projects / download resume).
The goal is to make the text block feel as visually strong as the illustration while keeping the same aesthetic and layout structure.

target_area.name: hero_text_block
target_area.description: The right-hand panel in the hero that contains the main name heading, the short descriptive sentence/tagline, and the two call-to-action buttons.

design_goals: Increase the visual prominence of the name and text block so it feels balanced with the large illustration on the left.
Maintain the existing dark, minimal, grid/dot aesthetic and overall layout.
Preserve all existing functionality of navigation, hero interactions, and buttons.
Ensure typography and spacing still look good on mobile, tablet, and desktop breakpoints.

heading_name.description: Make the main name heading ('MARIO CAMARENA') significantly larger and more dominant.
requirements: Increase the heading font size by roughly 40% compared to the current size on desktop.
On large screens, the name should visually read as the primary focal point of the right panel, clearly larger than the tagline text.
Use responsive typography so that on smaller screens the heading still fits comfortably without wrapping awkwardly or overflowing.
If using Tailwind, move the heading up by about one to two size steps at each relevant breakpoint (for example: base size one step larger, large/desktop size one step larger than before).
Keep the current font family and tracking style that gives it the tech/terminal feel; only adjust size and, if needed, line-height.

tagline_text.description: Slightly increase the supporting tagline text so it is easier to read and better matches the enlarged heading.
requirements: Increase the tagline font size by roughly 20% compared to the current size on desktop.
Maintain clear hierarchy so the tagline is still noticeably smaller than the main name heading.
Ensure comfortable line length and readability; adjust max width or line-height if the text looks too cramped.
On mobile, ensure the tagline does not feel tiny relative to the heading; bump the mobile size by at least one step if needed.

cta_buttons.description: Make the call-to-action buttons feel more substantial and clickable.
requirements: Increase horizontal and vertical padding by approximately 10–20% so the buttons look more substantial without becoming bulky.
Increase the button label font size by about one size step to match the slightly larger body text.
Keep the existing styling, colors, and hover/focus behavior; only adjust sizing/spacing.
Maintain the current layout (two buttons side by side on desktop, stacked or otherwise responsive layout on smaller screens if that already exists).

text_block_width_and_layout.description: Adjust the width and spacing of the hero text block so it visually balances with the illustration.
requirements: Allow the hero text block to occupy approximately 35–45% of the viewport width on large/desktop screens (while keeping the illustration and overall grid composition intact).
If there is a max-width or similar constraint on the text block, increase it moderately so the enlarged heading and tagline have enough room without wrapping too early.
Ensure spacing between heading, tagline, and buttons is adjusted proportionally so the block feels airy and intentional (no elements crammed together).
Do not change the relative left/right positioning of illustration vs. text; only adjust widths and internal spacing within the existing layout.
Verify that the hero looks good at typical breakpoints: small mobile, tablet, and desktop/large desktop.
On small screens, ensure the hero content still fits without clipping or requiring horizontal scrolling.
If necessary, slightly reduce the scaling of the heading on very small widths to prevent awkward wrapping, while still making it feel bolder than before.
Keep consistent visual hierarchy across all breakpoints: name > tagline > buttons.

constraints: Do not remove or rename existing components, routes, or navigation items.
Do not change copy/text content in this task; only adjust size, spacing, and layout within the hero text block.
Do not modify the left-side illustration or background grid other than minor spacing adjustments if strictly required to avoid layout issues.
Preserve all existing click behavior, routing, and analytics/events attached to the hero buttons and navigation.
acceptance_criteria: On a desktop viewport, the main name heading is clearly larger and visually dominant, approximately 1.4x its previous size.
The tagline is noticeably easier to read and about 1.2x its previous size while remaining secondary to the heading.
The hero buttons feel slightly larger and more inviting, with increased padding and readable text, without breaking their layout.
The right-hand text block occupies enough width that the overall hero feels visually balanced with the left illustration.
No existing functionality is broken, and the hero remains fully responsive across common screen sizes.
